line-height: 150%;">}</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%; margin: 0in -1.45pt .0001pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1" title=""><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">}</span></strong></span></a></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%; margin: 0in -1.1pt 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">}</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-align: center; margin: 0in -1.1pt 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">}</span></strong></span></p></td><td style="width: 94.05pt; padding: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt;" width="125"><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Md. Abdul Kader</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . Complainant-Petitioner</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The State and another</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">...Opposite-parties</span></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 265(c) </span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">A charge is an important step in a criminal proceeding. It separates the inquiry stage </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">from trial. The whole object of framing a charge</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;"> is to enable the defence to concentrate its attention on the case that he has to meet, and if charge is framed in such a vague manner that the necessary ingredients of the offence with which the accused is convicted are not brought out in the charge, then the charge is defective. The framing of a proper charge is vital to a criminal trial and this is a matter on which the Magistrate or Judge should bestow the most careful attention. A charge should be carefully drawn up in accordance with the offence disclosed. The charge should be precise in its scope and particular in its details. A charge is defined as a ‘precise formulation of the specific accusation made against a person who is </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">entitled to know its nature at the very earliest</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;"> stage. The necessity of a system of written </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">accusation specifying a definite criminal offence</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;"> is the essence of criminal procedure.      . . .(9)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Criminal Procedure (V of 1898)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Section 265(c)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Penal Code (LXV of 1860)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Sections 406, 409 and 420</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">On going to the materials on record it </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.4pt;">transpires that the complainant categorically</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> narrated the manner of crime committed by </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.5pt;">the accused. In judicial inquiry, all the witnesses</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> categorically stated that the accused is solely responsible for misappropriation of the amount. Therefore, the learned Magistrate after assessing the judicial inquiry report, found prima facie case against the accused and took cognizance of the offence. The learned Sessions Judge after considering the entire materials on record also took cognizance of the offence prescribed in Sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code against the accused. All that is required at the stage of framing charge is to see whether the prima-facie case regarding commission of certain offence is made out. The truth veracity and effect of evidence which prosecution proposes to adduce at the time is not to be meticulously judged at the stage of framing charge. In the instant case the accused stand indicted for offence punishable under Sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code. Cognizance has been taken </span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">under the said sections. We have gone through</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> the grounds taken in the application for discharge filed under Section 265C of the Code and we find that such grounds are absolutely the disputed question of facts and the same should be decided at trial. The plea of the accused are nothing but the defence plea. Be that as it may the proposition of law is now well settled that on the basis of defence plea or materials the criminal proceedings should not be stifled before trial; when there is a prima-facie case for going for trial.                                                   . . .(12)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mr. Jafar Alim Khan, Advocate,</span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . . For the Complainant-petitioner</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mrs. Sakila Rowshan,D.A.G. with</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">Mrs. Sharmina Haque, A.A.G. and</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Shorwardhi, A.A.G.</span></span></p><p align="right" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: right; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">. . . For the State-opposite party No. 1.</span></em></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-left: .5in; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Shamsur Rahman, Advocate,</span></span></p><p align="right" class="CM15" style="text-align: right; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">...For the accused-opposite party No.2</span></em></strong> </span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center; line-height: 150%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 150%;">JUDGMENT</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Syed Md. Ziaul Karim, J:</span></u></strong> <span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">By this Rule, complainant-petitioner has challenged the legality and propriety of the order dated 06-09-2005 passed by learned Sessions Judge, Brahmanbaria, allowing an application under Section 265C of the Code of Criminal Procedure (briefly as the Code)filed by the accused opposite party and discharged him in Session Case no. 98 of 2005 arising out of C.R. no. 117 of 2005 under Sections 406,409, 420 of the Penal Code.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Facts in brief are that on 08-02-2005 the petitioner as complainant filed a petition of complaint in the Court of Magistrate, First Class, Brahmmanbaria accusing the accused opposite party alleging that since 05-03-2002 to 11-07-2003, the accused as Chairman of Kuthi Union Parishad collected tax for Tk. 84,158.00 from different persons but without depositing the same in the Government <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">treasury misappropriated it. Thereby committed</span> the offence prescribed under Sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">On receipt of the complaint the learned Magistrate held judicial inquiry into the allegations made by the complainant. To that effect the complainant adduced six witnesses and the defence also produced a good number of witnesses. On receipt of the inquiry report the learned Magistrate, after assessing the report came to a finding that prima-facie case of criminal breach of trust had been disclosed against the accused. Thereby he took cognizance of the offence. Later, he referred the case to the Sessions Judge for trial. On receipt of the case record dated 07-06-2005 the learned Sessions Judge took cognizance of the offence under Sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code. Eventually, fixing 27-07-2005 for framing charge.  Subsequently and on the same day on behalf of the accused an application under Section 265C of the Code was filed by the accused stating that the complaint was filed at a belated stage and he was not responsible for collecting tax. Afterwards the learned Sessions Judge by the impugned order dated 06-09-2005 allowed the application under Section 265C of the Code and thereby discharged the accused from the case. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Feeling aggrieved the complainant as petitioner preferred the instant Revision and obtained the present Rule.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The learned Advocate appearing on behalf of the complainant petitioner and the learned Deputy Attorney General appearing on behalf of the State opposite party no.1 oppose the Rule.Their common contentions are that the petitioner by collecting tax misappropriated the whole amount without depositing it in the Government treasury. The grounds taken in the application for discharge are nothing but the defence plea which can be decided at the time of trial. So the learned Sessions Judge without framing charge committed illegality which calls for interference by this Court. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The learned Advocate appearing for the accused –opposite party no.2 opposes the Rule and submits that the accused was not responsible in collecting tax. So he has no liability in respect of misappropriation. Thereby the learned Sessions Judge rightly discharged the accused. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In order to appreciate their submissions we have gone through the record and given our anxious consideration to their submissions.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.35pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black; text-transform: uppercase;">W</span></em><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">e should bear in mind, credibility of testimony oral and circumstantial, depends considerably on a judicial evaluation of the totality, not isolated scrutiny. When dealing with the serious question of guilt or innocence of persons charged with crime, the following principles should be taken into consideration. </span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; mso-list: l0 level4 lfo1; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">a)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">The onus of proving everything essential to the establishment of the charge against the accused lies on the prosecutor.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level4 lfo1; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">b)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; color: black;">The evidence must be such asto exclude to a moral certainty every reasonable doubt of the guilt of the accused.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; mso-list: l0 level4 lfo1; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">c)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">In matters of doubt it is safer to acquit than to condemn, for it is better that several guilty persons should escape than that one innocent person suffer.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; mso-list: l0 level4 lfo1; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">d)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">There must be clear and unequivocal proof of the corpus delicit.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; mso-list: l0 level4 lfo1; tab-stops: 45.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">e)<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></em></strong><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">The hypothesis of delinquency should be consistent with all the facts proved.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">Inspite of the presumption of truth attached to oral evidence under oath if the Court is not satisfied, the evidence inspite of oath is of no avail.</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">A "Charge" corresponds to an "indictment" in English Law and is very much more than a mere form. It is a precise formulation of specific accusation made against a person. Charge has to be framed on the basis of the material placed before the Trial Court and while doing so the Court is not bound by the inquiry report submitted under section 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure or in a Police challan case by the report submitted under section 173 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">            </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">A charge is an important step in a criminal proceeding. It separates the inquiry stage from trial. The whole object of framing a charge is to enable the defence to concentrate its attention on the case that he has to meet, and if charge is framed in such a vague manner that the necessary ingredients of the offence with which the accused is convicted are not brought out in the charge, then the charge is defective. The framing of a proper charge is vital to a criminal trial and this is a matter on which the Magistrate or Judge should bestow the most careful attention. A charge should be carefully drawn up in accordance with the offence disclosed. The charge should be precise in its scope and particular in its details. A charge is defined as a ‘precise formulation of the specific accusation made against a person who is entitled to know its nature at the very earliest stage. The necessity of a system of written accusation specifying a definite criminal offence is the essence of criminal procedure. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 10.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; color: black;">By taking cognizance the accused is called upon to plead is a very important document. It should be drawn up and considered with extreme care and caution, so that accused may have no doubt whatever as to the offences to which he is called upon to answer and the Judge of the Appellate Court also may have no doubt upon the matter. The word ‘Ground’ means basis, foundation or valid reason. The whole object of framing a charge is to enable the defence to concentrate its attention on the case that he has to meet. Conditions for framing of a charge are (i) presumption of the commission of an offence <span style="letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">on the materials before the Court and (ii) offences</span> triable exclusively by a competent Court.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the case of Mohd. Aqil and another Vs. The State 1988 Crl. L.J. 1484 held:</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 6.0pt .25in;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">" Framing of charge- Matters to be considered by Court indicated.</span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: .25in; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt .25in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><em><span style="font-size: 11pt;">For the purpose of framing a charge the Court is required to consider judicially asto whether on consideration of the materials on record, it can be said that the accused has reasonably connected himself with the offence alleged to have been committed and that on the basis of the said material there is reasonable probability or chance of the accused  being found guilty of the offence alleged. If the answer is in the affirmative, the Court will be at liberty to presume "that the accused has committed the offence” as mentioned in S. 228 for the purpose of framing the charge. In finding out a prima-facie case not only the F.I.R. or complaint but even the statements of the witnesses recorded under S. 161 although the same may have been recorded after some delay during the investigation of the case are to be taken into consideration and if from all other material, a prima facie case is made out against the accused then the Magistrate has no option but to frame a charge against the accused. The Court is not expected to make a roving enquiry in the pros and cons of the matter and weigh the evidence as if he was conducting a trial. However, in a case, if two views are possible and the Judge is satisfied that evidence produced before him while giving rise to some suspicion does not give rise to grave suspicion against the accused, he will  be fully within his right to discharge the accused."</span></em></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">On going to the materials on record it transpires that the complainant categorically narrated the manner of crime committed by the accused. In judicial inquiry, all the witnesses categorically stated that the accused is solely responsible for misappropriation of the amount. Therefore, the learned Magistrate after assessing the judicial inquiry report, found prima facie case against the accused and took cognizance of the offence. The learned Sessions Judge after considering the entire materials on record also took cognizance of the offence prescribed in Sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code against the accused. All that is required at the stage of framing charge is to see whether the prima-facie case regarding commission of certain offence is made out. The truth veracity and effect of evidence which prosecution proposes to adduce at the time is not to be meticulously judged at the stage of framing charge. In the instant case the accused stand indicted for offence punishable under Sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code. Cognizance has been taken under the said sections. We have meticulously examined the allegations made by the complainant and we find that the offences punishable under Sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code have been clearly disclosed in the instant case. We have gone through the grounds taken in the application for discharge filed under Section 265C of the Code and we find that such grounds are absolutely the disputed question of facts and the same should be decided at trial. The plea of the accused are nothing but the defence plea. Be that as it may the proposition of law is now well settled that on the basis of defence plea or materials the criminal proceedings should not be stifled before trial; when there is a prima-facie case for going for trial. In view of such facts the grounds taken for discharge by the learned Judge are not the correct exposition of law. Moreso interruption of the course of Justice will set up a wrong precedent by which the course of justice instead of being advanced readily been stifled inasmuchas the grounds advanced before us by the learned Counsel for the defence are not correct or legal exposition of law. Therefore we hold that there are sufficient grounds for proceeding against the accused for going for trial under sections 406, 409, 420 of the Penal Code. To that end in view we are not at one with the learned Judge of the Court below regarding discharge of the accused. In view of the above we find merit in this revision. Thus the revision having merit succeeds.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">        </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In view of foregoing narrative the Rule is made absolute. The impugned order dated 06-09-2005 passed by the learned Sessions Judge, Brahmmanbaria in Session Case no. 98 of 2005 is hereby set-aside. The Session Case No. 98 of 2005 shall proceed in accordance with law and in the light of observations made above.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">         Office is directed to send down the record at once.</span></p><p class="Default" style="text-indent: 30.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Ed. </span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Criminal Revision No. </span></strong></a><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">203 of 2006.</span></strong></span></p></div></div></div></div>

Name="Light Grid Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64"  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 3"/>  <w:LsdException style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">(CIVIL)</span></strong></span></p><div align="center"><table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" Nizamul Huq, J</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin: 0in; margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Judgment on</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">12.07.2016</span></strong></span></p></td><td style="width: 16.1pt; padding: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; height: 112.85pt;" width="21"><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 200%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 200%;">}</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 200%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 200%;">}</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center; line-height: 200%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftn1" name="_ftnref1" title=""><span class="MsoFootnoteReference"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 200%;">}</span></strong></span></a></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="margin-left: 0in; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">}</span></strong></span></p></td><td style="width: 93.55pt; padding: 0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt; height: 112.85pt;" width="125"><p class="CM4"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Md. Amir Hossain</span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="CM4" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Petitioner</span></strong></span></p><p align="center" class="Default" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">-Versus-</span></strong></span></p><p class="Default"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span lang="EN" style="font-size: 11pt;">Baby Bewa and others </span></strong></span></p><p align="right" class="Default" style="text-align: right;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">. . . Respondents </span></strong></span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-top: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; mso-layout-grid-align: none; text-autospace: none;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Code of Civil Procedure (V of 1908)</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; tab-stops: 0in 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Order XXIII, Rule 3</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 110%; tab-stops: right 210.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The High Court Division observed that the petitioner and opposite party No. 24 (Md. Abdul Jalil Baki) through entering <em>solenama</em> divided some portion of the suit land amongst themselves in an <em>ex parte </em>decree wherein 23 other co-sharers of the property were left out. The High Court Division observed that the appellate Court rightly pointed out that the 23 appellants had been deprived of their legal right to get the property partitioned in accordance with law. When any number of parties to a suit reach a compromise in the absence of other parties, clearly those, who are excluded from the compromise, are deprived of their opportunity to put forward any claim that they may have in the suit land. The impugned judgement does not suffer from any illegality or impropriety and does not call for any interference by this Division.</span></strong><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">                    . . . (12 to 14)</span></strong></span></p><h5 style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-style: normal;">For the Petitioner : </span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;">Mr.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;"> Md.</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-weight: normal; font-style: normal;"> Abdur Razzak Miah, Advocate, instructed by Mr. Zahirul Islam, Advocate-on-Record.</span></span></h5><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;">For Respondent Nos. 1-23 :</span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; letter-spacing: -0.3pt;"> Mr. Munsur</span><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;"> Habib, Advocate, instructed by Mr. Gias Uddin Ahmed, Advocate-on-Record.</span></span></p><h6 style="text-align: justify; text-indent: -.5in; line-height: 110%; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 1.0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;">For Respondent Nos. 24-50 :<span style="font-weight: normal;"> Not represented.</span></span></h6><p align="center" class="CM1" style="margin-bottom: 6.0pt; text-align: center; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">JUDGMENT</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 27.0pt; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%; font-variant: small-caps;">Muhammad Imman Ali, J:</span></u></strong><u> </u><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">This civil petition for leave to appeal is directed against the judgement and order dated 13.05.2012 passed by a Division Bench of the High Court Division in Civil Revision No.542 of 2010 discharging the Rule. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">2.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The facts, relevant for disposal of the instant civil petition for leave to appeal, are that Abdul Jalil Baki respondent No.24 herein as plaintiff instituted Other Suit No.138 of 2008 in the Court of Joint District Judge, First Court, Bogra, for setting aside the preliminary decree dated 24.08.2006 and final decree dated 24.11.2007 passed in Partition Suit No. 2 of 2004. He stated, <em>inter alia, </em>that Mst. Rezia and Motiar Rahman defendant Nos.48 and 49 respectively mortgaged the suit property to Rupali Bank, and since they failed to repay the loan, Rupali Bank filed Artha Rin Case No.129 of 2000 and the suit was decreed and, thereafter, Money Execution Case No.233 of 2007 was filed and in that execution case the property was auction sold and the plaintiff purchased 1.27 acres of land out of 1.53 acres of Plot No.28 and got possession of the case land through Court. The further case of the plaintiff is that Amir Hossain defendant No. 1 by manufacturing some false papers claimed that he purchased land of Plot No.28 from Azizur Rahman (defendant No. 47) his predecessor and, thereafter, claiming as a co-sharer he filed Partition Suit No.2 of 2004, and by showing false service got an <em>ex parte </em>decree on 24.8.2006 and on the basis of such false decree obtained final decree on 28.10.2007. When the defendant went to take possession, the plaintiff learnt about the partition decree and then filed the instant suit.  </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 109%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">3.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">The petitioner herein as defendant contested the suit by filing written statement and denied the claim of the plaintiff. He contended, <em>inter alia, </em>that the suit property belonged to Mrs. Hameda Mohammad Ali, wife of late Mohammad Ali, Ex-Prime Minister of Pakistan and after her death her son Hatem Ali Chowdhury got the property through a family arrangement and sold the same to the petitioner. The petitioner after purchasing the suit property took possession of the land through Court and established a Madrasha, which is known as Abdul Jabbar Madrasha with a Hostel built therein for the students. He also planted 250 saplings. When the petitioner learnt about the Partition Suit No.55 of 2000 in respect of the suit property, he got himself added as a defendant and filed written statement. Thereafter, the plaintiff did not proceed with the suit and the same was dismissed for default. Then the petitioner filed Partition Suit No.2 of 2004 to demarcate his purchased land, but as the defendant did not contest the suit, the said suit was decreed <em>ex parte </em>and the final decree was passed on 28.11.2007. He filed Partition Execution Case No.6 of 2008 and by an order of the Court dated 30.08.2008 an Advocate Commissioner was appointed. When they went to the suit land the plaintiff did not allow them to enter into the land, so the Advocate Commissioner with the help of police gave possession of the suit land to the petitioner. Thereafter, the petitioner and Abdul Jalil Baki in order to resolve the dispute about their interest in the suit land filed a compromise petition. The Joint District Judge allowed the compromise petition and the suit was disposed of as per terms of the <em>solenama</em>. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">4.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">The petitioner claimed that opposite party Nos. 1-23 in the civil revision before the High Court Division (respondent Nos. 1-23 herein) were defendant Nos. 23-45 in the said suit, but did not contest the suit nor filed any written statement.  The compromise petition between the petitioner and opposite party No.24 Abdul Jalil Baki related to Plot No.28, which comprised 1.53 acres of land and the petitioner claimed 78 decimals out of it and the respondents claimed rest of the land in Plot No.28. He stated that respondent Nos.1-23 had no interest in that plot. They have not been affected by the compromise and, if they are aggrieved, they could file a partition suit to state their claim, if there is any, in the suit land. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">5.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Respondent Nos.1-23 by filing counter affidavit before the High Court Division stated that the compromise petition filed by Mohammad Amir Hussain, the petitioner with Md. Abdul Jalil Baki, opposite party No. 24 in the civil revision, (respondent No. 24 herein) was illegal and could not be entertained. The joint District Judge, 1<sup>st</sup> Court, Bogra committed an error of law in accepting the compromise petition overlooking the nature of the suit and declaring the final decree dated 24.08.2006 in Partition Suit No.02 of 2004, which was collusive, null and void and not acted upon and, therefore, confers no title and interest upon the suit land and prayed for setting aside the said decree dated 24.08.2006 passed in Partition Suit No.02 of 2004.    </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 109%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">6.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 109%;">Respondent Nos. 1-23 (defendant Nos.23-45 of the Partition Suit No.02 of 2004), claimed that they did not receive any notice of the Partition Suit No.02 of 2004, in the Court of Joint District Judge, 1<sup>st</sup> Court, Bogra and the decree was obtained by the plaintiff by practicing fraud upon the Court, and as such, Other Suit No.138 of 2008 is required to be proceeded up to its finality to look into the matter whether the <em>ex-parte </em>decree passed in Partition Suit No.02 of 2004 was correct. They claimed to have right, title, interest and possession in the suit land and they are seriously prejudiced by the <em>ex-parte </em>decree passed on 24.08.2006 and had they been aware of the filing of Partition Suit No.02 of 2004 they would have contested the suit claiming their saham. They further claimed that the judgement dated 20.01.2010 passed in Other Class Appeal No. 147 of 2009 allowing the appeal was correct in setting aside the order dated 24.05.2009 in Other Class Suit No. 138 of 2008, however, the appellate Court in Other Class Appeal No. 147 of 2009 failed to notice the nature of the suit and the prayer of Other Class Suit No. 138 of 2008, wherein the Court decreed the suit in terms of the final decree dated 24.08.2006 in Partition Suit No. 02 of 2004, which was illegal, collusive and null and void and bore no right, title and interest for Abdul Jalil Baki in schedule Nos. 1 and 2 of the plaint. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">7.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">After hearing the parties and considering the evidence and materials on record, the Joint District Judge, First Court, Bogra, allowed the compromise petition and the suit was thus disposed of as per terms of the <em>solenama</em> by the judgement and decree dated 24.05.2009. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">8.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Being aggrieved, the defendant Nos.1-23 preferred Title Appeal No.147 of 2009 before the District Judge, Bogra and the same was heard by the 1<sup>st</sup> Additional District Judge, Bogra, who by his judgement and decree dated 20.01.2010 allowed the appeal. Then the plaintiff preferred Civil Revision No.542 of 2010 before the High Court Division and obtained Rule, which upon hearing the parties was discharged. Hence, the plaintiff is now before us having filed the civil petition for leave to appeal.     </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; line-height: 110%; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">9.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">      </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; line-height: 110%;">Mr. Md. Abdur Rezzaque Miah, learned Advocate appearing on behalf of the petitioner submitted that the High Court Division did not apply its mind in evaluating the facts and materials on record since there is proof available in the record of the case that the defendants of Other Class Suit No. 138 of 2008 received notice of the suit in time, but they did not contest and claim their saham in the suit land. He also submitted that the High Court Division failed to appreciate that the decree passed in Other Class Suit No. 138 of 2008 has been validly executed by the petitioner and respondent No. 24 to settle the dispute in respect of land of plot no. 28 where present respondent Nos. 1 to 23 had no interest and the Joint District Judge, First Court, Bogra, rightly determined the suit based on the <em>solenama</em> and declaring the terms of the <em>solenama</em> as part of the decree and hence, the impugned judgement is liable to be set aside. He further submitted that the High Court Division failed to appreciate that admittedly defendant Nos. 48 and 49 of the original suit mortgaged the suit property with Rupali Bank and when they failed to repay the loan, the bank filed Artha Rin Case No. 129 of 2000 and the suit was decreed. Thereafter, the bank filed Money Execution Case No. 233 of 2007 and in due course the property was sold in auction and respondent No. 24 purchased 75 decimals of land of plot No. 28 and got possession thereof through Court, it has been clearly described in the <em>solenama</em>, and hence, the High Court Division erred in discharging the Rule on the ground that 23 co-sharers of the property were left out of the <em>solenama</em>.   </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">10.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Mr. Munsur Habib,</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;"> learned Advocate appearing for respondent Nos.1-23 made submissions in support of the impugned judgement and order of the High Court Division.  </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">11.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">We find from the judgement of the appellate Court, being the last court of fact that out of the 7.24 acres of land detailed in the schedule, there was no apportionment of the property in respect of 51 defendants and that the plaint and written statement did not resolve the controversy between the parties entirely the <em>solenama</em> was signed by the plaintiff Md. Abdul Jalil Baki and Md. Amir Hossain on behalf of the defendants. These two persons are not the sole owners of the property in the <em>jote. </em>It was observed by the appellate Court that the 23 appellants, who are defendants in the suit, were not party to the <em>solenama</em>.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: 0in list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">12.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">The High Court Division observed that the petitioner and opposite party No. 24 (Md. Abdul Jalil Baki) through entering <em>solenama</em> </span><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: 0.1pt;">divided some portion of the suit land amongst </span><span style="font-size: 11pt;">be clouded. Whatever, title the decree holder bank got in respect of the mortgaged property is subject to the right, title and interest of the judgment debtors had in the </span><span style="font-size: 11pt;">themselves in an <em>ex parte </em>decree wherein 23 other co-sharers of the property were left out. The High Court Division observed that the appellate Court rightly pointed out that the 23 appellants had been deprived of their legal right to get the property partitioned in accordance with law.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">13.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">When any number of parties to a suit reach a compromise in the absence of other parties, clearly those, who are excluded from the compromise, are deprived of their opportunity to put forward any claim that they may have in the suit land. </span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in; mso-list: l0 level1 lfo1; tab-stops: list .25in left 27.0pt; margin: 0in 0in 12.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">14.<span style="font-style: normal; font-weight: normal; font-size: 7pt; line-height: normal; font-size-adjust: none; font-stretch: normal; font-feature-settings: normal; font-language-override: normal; font-kerning: auto; font-synthesis: weight style; font-variant: normal;">  </span></span></strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">In the facts and circumstances discussed above, we are of the view that the impugned judgement does not suffer from any illegality or impropriety and does not call for any interference by this Division. </span></span></p><p class="CM4" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 11pt;">         Accordingly, the civil petition for leave to appeal is dismissed.</span></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-indent: .5in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Ed.</span></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: 12.0pt; text-align: justify; tab-stops: 0in 27.0pt;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt; letter-spacing: 0.1pt;"> </span></strong></span></p><div style="mso-element: footnote-list;"><br clear="all"/><hr align="left" size="1" width="33%"/><div id="ftn1" style="mso-element: footnote;"><p class="MsoNormal" style="line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><a href="#_ftnref1" name="_ftn1" title=""><strong><u><span style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%;">CIVIL PETITION FOR  LEAVE TO AP</span></u></strong></a><strong><u><span style="font-size: 10pt; line-height: 110%;">PEAL  No. 1789 OF  2013</span></u></strong></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: justify; line-height: 110%;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><span style="font-size: 9pt; line-height: 110%;">(From the judgment and order dated 13<sup>th</sup> of May, 2012 passed by the High Court Division in Civil Revision No.542 of 2010).</span></span></p></div></div></div></div>

<w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="62" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Light Grid Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="63" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="64" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Shading 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="65" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="66" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium List 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="67" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 1 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="68" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 2 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="69" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Medium Grid 3 Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="70" SemiHidden="false"   UnhideWhenUsed="false" Name="Dark List Accent 5"/>  <w:LsdException Locked="false" Priority="71" SemiHidden="false" </strong></span></p><p align="center" class="MsoNormal" style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: class="MsoBodyTextIndent" style="text-align: center; line-height: 200%; margin: 0in -1.1pt 6.0pt 0in;"><span style="font-family: times new roman,times,serif;"><strong><span style="font-size: 11pt;
